Yohanes Santoso wrote:
> > Can you give some use cases where queries are *needed* (beyond one 
> > query
> > parameter?)
> 
> For unstructured search (like google's basic search), you 
> pretty much gives only one kind of input.
> 
> For structured search (like google's advance search), you 
> need to 'type' each input. For example, if I supply 
> "2006-10-20", I want to type it as the modification date, 
> instead of a string somewhere in the body of a page.

Ah.   

BTW, and this is a philosophy point, encoding into a single string for a
search query IMO is probably the better way to go because then it is
resilient to change.  Splitting out into different parameters means the
interface might need to change when you add new features.  This is
essentially the same argument for why the URL as a single string is better
than an EPR[1].

Also, could you not encode date into the URL path?
